newsitem.title: UK: PRESS DIGEST - FINANCIAL TIMES - AUGUST 7.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - FINANCIAL TIMES - AUGUST 7.

text.p: This daily press summary is produced for Reuters by the Broadcast Monitoring Company, which is responsible for its contents.
-- FOOTSIE FLIES PAST THE 5,000 LEVEL

Following a sharp fall in sterling and expectations that the Bank of England's monetary policy committee might not raise interest rates, the FTSE 100 index rose beyond 5,000 for the first time ever, increasing by 65.6 to close at 5,026.2 with sterling down during the day to close at $1.601 and DM3.001 in London and closing at $1.6022 and DM3.0135 later in New York.
-- AILING APPLE UNVEILS LINK WITH MICROSOFT

Software giant Microsoft took a small $150 million share in Apple Computer as the Macintosh manufacturer's co-founder Steve Jobs announced Apple's intention to team up with its age-old rival to help the struggling company from sinking any further. In addition, Apple added three new members to its board, the chief executives of Oracle and Intuit and the chief financial officer of International Business Machines; Larry Ellison, Bill Campbell, and Jerry York, respectively.
-- STRONG POUND WILL BRING "RECESSION BY 1999"

Leading economics forecast group Cambridge Econometrics revealed the results of a forecast that predicts that, if sterling averages as much as DM2.80 over the next three years rather than a steady depreciation to DM2.35, goods and services output will be 2 percent lower by 2000 with a recession likely in 1999. The textiles, paper and parts of the engineering and tourism sectors are likely to be worst affected, says Cambridge.
-- NIE AND REGULATOR MAY FACE COURT BATTLE

Northern Ireland Electricity regulator Ofreg has over-ruled recommendations by the Monopolies and Mergers Commission concerning the price control of the Province's electricity monopoly NIE and the whole case seems likely to end up in court before a final decision can be made. The issue is the first of its kind where a utilities regulator has superseded the advice of the MMC.
-- CHANNEL 5 CHIEF CONFIDENT OF HITTING TARGETS

Channel 5's chief executive David Elstein has rejected private calls from company executives to increase the channel's budget from 110m stg to 160m stg a year to increase ratings from the present 3.1 percent to its targeted 5 percent of the total viewing population. Mr Elstein commented that the challenge was to make Channel 5 work on its budget and that anyone could do it on 160 million stg a year.
-- BA STAFF SICKNESS DELAYS RETURN TO NORMAL SERVICE

British Airways has announced that it could be a further 10 days before its Heathrow flight schedule returns to normal following the continuing sickness of its cabin crew staff because although only 300 of its staff went on the 3-day strike a further 2,000 staff called in sick. Numbers of cabin registered sick yesterday at Heathrow was 30 percent less than four days ago and 98 percent of flights are running as normal.
-- 12M STG AVAILABLE TO REDUCE FLEET OF TRAWLERS FURTHER

Fisheries minister Elliot Morley has announced that there is still a further 12 million stg available to the UK fishing industry for the decommissioning of vessels and tenders on a value-for-money basis to further reduce UK registered fishing tonnage by a further 4 percent to meet the EU's MAGP III capacity cuts ruling. In the past four years 578 vessels have been decommissioned at a cost of 36 million stg, reducing the fishing fleet by 26 percent.
-- BOOTS TO LAUNCH LOYALTY CARD

High street pharmacy chain Boots has launched its customer loyalty card, giving consumers points for discounts on mainly-women's purchases in 1,200 stores, after trials in its stores in Norfolk and Devon have helped the retailer to predict an elevation in sales by four percent. The scheme is costing Boots 52 million stg over the next three years and expects to have eight million customers signed up for it by September next year.
-- PRU DOUBLES FUNDS FOR PENSIONS PAYBACK

The UK's biggest pensions and life assurance group Prudential Corporation has boosted its provision for the compensation of pension mis-selling victims from 240 million stg to 450 million stg following warnings from the Association of British Insurers that mis-selling and other compensation costs are likely to exceed 4 billion stg. Prudential are hoping to clear-up all outstanding cases by its deadline next March after pressure on the pensions industry from the government.
-- CORTECS TO UNVEIL PROMISING RESULTS ON OSTEOPOROSIS DRUG

UK-based biotechnology company Cortecs has announced the promising success of its new drug, for the treatment of the bone disease osteoporosis, Macritonin after recent failures in drug trials. The new drug is to be submitted to regulators this month and is expected to be launched next year. Stockbrokers Lehman Brothers' analysts commented that sales of the drug are expected to reach $250m by 2003, leaving shares at half of their 12 month high at 162.5p.
